unnormalised: The year was 2005. I remember Amma yelling at me for hogging the "inter-net" on our BSNL landline. Back then, "www." was practically sacred, typed religiously before every address, even though browsers did it automatically. My Orkut profile was my pride and joy, carefully curated with embarrassing testimonials from school friends. The "net" was a magical place, full of chat rooms and dial-up tones, so different from today. We measured internet speeds in kbps, not mbps or gbps, and waiting 5 mins for a single image to load was normal.
normalised: The year was two thousand and five. I remember Amma yelling at me for hogging the "inter-net" on our B-S-N-L landline. Back then, "W-W-W dot" was practically sacred, typed religiously before every address, even though browsers did it automatically. My Orkut profile was my pride and joy, carefully curated with embarrassing testimonials from school friends. The "net" was a magical place, full of chat rooms and dial-up tones, so different from today. We measured internet speeds in kilobits per second, not megabits per second or gigabits per second, and waiting five minutes for a single image to load was normal.

unnormalised: I learned HTML from a "dot com" tutorial, building Geocities sites for my friends' imaginary businesses. "Email id's" were a status symbol, particularly if you snagged a cool Yahoo! or Hotmail address. Social media was nascent; Facebook was still an exclusive club for college students, and "tweeting" wasn't even a word. Remember those forwarded chain emails promising you good luck if you sent it to 10 ppl? Ah, simpler times.
normalised: I learned H-T-M-L from a "dot com" tutorial, building Geocities sites for my friends' imaginary businesses. "Email I-D's" were a status symbol, particularly if you snagged a cool Yahoo! or Hotmail address. Social media was nascent; Facebook was still an exclusive club for college students, and "tweeting" wasn't even a word. Remember those forwarded chain emails promising you good luck if you sent it to ten people? Ah, simpler times.

unnormalised: Then came the broadband revolution. Suddenly, the "net" wasn't a chore but a convenience. YouTube appeared, and overnight we could watch grainy music videos instead of waiting for them on MTV. Downloading songs on Napster (shhh!) became way faster (but not necessarily legal). Wikipedia became my go-to source for homework, even though Sir often warned us against its accuracy. I also remember painstakingly creating my first "blog" on Blogger, using it as a personal diary.

unnormalised: The mobile internet changed everything. The shift from GPRS to 3G and then 4G was astonishing. Suddenly, I could be online everywhere—commuting on the local train, waiting for my chai at the tapri. The "net" went mobile. Facebook and WhatsApp dominated, and short, bite-sized content ruled. Memes replaced forwarded emails, and "viral" videos were the new gossip.

unnormalised: Now, we’re all preparing for 5G. The "cloud" is everywhere, and "AI" is the buzzword. I sometimes wonder what Amma would think of this "inter-net" now, with its endless apps, streaming services, and instant connectivity. What was once a luxury is now a necessity, woven into the fabric of our lives. From slow dial-up to light-speed broadband, the "net" has come a long way, bhai.
